To the north of it, there is a pond, where a fragrant elephant served his mother.
In the past, when the TathÄgata was practicing the bodhisattva path, he was the son of a fragrant elephant, living in the northern mountains, roaming by this pond.
His mother was blind, so he picked lotus roots and drew clear water, respectfully practicing filial piety, with time passing.
At that time, there was a person who wandered in the forest, lost his way, wandered around, and wailed in grief.
The elephant son heard this and felt pity for him, guiding him to show him the way back home.
After this person returned, he reported to the king, saying:
I know where the fragrant elephant roams in the forest. This is a rare treasure. You can go and capture it.
The king accepted his words, raised troops to go hunting, and this man led the way, pointing out the elephant to the king, and his two arms immediately fell off, as if they had been cut off.
Although the king was surprised by this anomaly, he still captured the elephant calf and returned.
The elephant calf had already been tethered for many days and did not eat water or grass. The keeper reported this to the king, who then personally questioned the elephant calf.
The elephant calf said:
My mother is blind and has been hungry for many days. Now that I see her in distress, how can I enjoy eating?
The king pitied its feelings and therefore released it.
Beside it is a stupa, in front of which is a stone pillar. This is where Kashyapa Buddha once sat in meditation.
Beside it are the remains of the seats and walking places of the four past Buddhas.
East of the seat of the four Buddhas, crossing the Maha River, there is a great forest, in which there is a stone pillar, the place where non-Buddhists entered concentration and made evil vows.
In the past, there was an outsider named Udraka RÄmaputra, who had lofty aspirations and lived in the grass and marshes. He dwelled in this Dharma forest, hiding his spirit and concealing his traces.
He possessed the five supernatural powers and attained the concentration of the highest existence.
The king of Magadha had deep respect for him and would invite him to the palace for meals at noon.
Udraka RÄmaputra would traverse the sky and come without fail.
The king of Magadha would look forward to his arrival and, when he arrived, would receive him and seat him.
When the king was about to go on a journey, he wanted to entrust matters to someone, but he could not find anyone in the palace who was suitable to receive the order.
He had a young daughter who was virtuous and dignified. She was both intimate and wise, and there was no one to her right. The king of Magadha summoned her and said:
I am going on a long journey and want to entrust something to you. You should be careful and complete the task well.
The sage Udraka has long been respected by me. When it is time for his meal, receive him as I would.
Having given the order, he then went on a tour of inspection.
The young girl, following the instructions, watched and waited in accordance with the proper etiquette. When the great sage arrived, she held him up and placed him on a seat.
Uttara, having touched a woman, gave rise to desire-realm defilements, lost his spiritual powers, finished his meal, and was told to return, unable to roam freely.
Feeling ashamed in his heart, he deceitfully said to the girl:

I have been cultivating the path, entering concentration and harmonizing the spirit, flying through the air coming and going, with little leisure time. The people of the country wish to see me, and have heard of this for a long time.
However, the teachings of the sages of the past take benefiting beings as their task. How can one cling to one's own goodness and forget about benefiting others?
Now I wish to leave through the gate, walk on the ground and go, so that those who see me will all receive blessings and benefits.
When the princess heard this, she announced it far and wide.
At that time, the people rushed to sprinkle and sweep the roads. Tens of millions of people stood waiting, looking forward to his arrival.

UruvilvÄ KÄÅ›yapa walked from the king's palace to the Dharma Grove, sat in meditation, but his mind wandered outside. When staying in the forest, crows and birds chirped; by the pond, fish and turtles made a commotion. His emotions scattered and his mind was disturbed, losing his spiritual power and neglecting his concentration.
He then gave rise to anger and made an evil vow:

May I become a ferocious beast in the future, with a cat's body and a bird's wings, swooping down to eat living creatures. My body will be three thousand miles wide, each of my two wings will be one thousand five hundred miles wide. I will enter the forest to eat the feathered tribes, and enter the water to eat the water creatures.
After making the vow, his angry mind gradually subsided. After diligently seeking for a while, he regained his original concentration.
Before long, his life ended and he was reborn in the heaven of the first meditative state, with a lifespan of eighty thousand eons.
The TathÄgata predicted that after the heavenly lifespan was exhausted, he would fulfill his past vow and obtain this evil body.
From then on, he transmigrated in the evil paths, without a time to escape.

Going east into the great forest for more than a hundred li from the east of Mohe River, he reached Kukkuá¹­apÄda Mountain (meaning chicken foot in Chinese), also called Gá¹›dhrakÅ«á¹­a Mountain (meaning vulture peak in Chinese).

The high peaks are steep, with no end in sight, and the deep valleys have no limit. At the foot of the mountain, in the valleys, tall forests cover the valleys, and on the mountain peaks and ridges, dense grass covers the cliffs. Three peaks rise up, with steep cliffs standing out beside them, their aura reaching the heavens, their shape the same as the clouds.
After that, Venerable MahÄkÄÅ›yapa resided there in tranquility, not daring to point it out, so it is called venerable foot.

For many eons, I diligently practiced austerities, seeking the unsurpassed Dharma for all beings. My wishes from the past have now been fulfilled.

When Maitreya, the future World-Honored One, appears in the world, after expounding the Dharma in the three assemblies, there will still be countless arrogant beings who will ascend this mountain and reach where KÄÅ›yapa is.

The assembly looked up to him, their arrogant minds were removed, and they were inspired and all attained the holy fruits.
Therefore, a stupa was built on the mountain. In the quiet night, when seen from a distance, there are sometimes bright torches, but when one climbs the mountain, nothing is seen.
Going more than a hundred li to the northeast of Mount Jiashen, I reached Mount Budhana.
The peaks and cliffs are lofty, the ridges and cliffs are hidden, and in the rocky caves, the Buddha once descended and stayed.
Beside it, there is a flat rock where Indra and Brahma smeared cow-head sandalwood on the Tathagata. Now, the remaining fragrance is strong on the rock.

Five hundred arhats secretly reside here. Those who have a connection may see them. Sometimes they appear in the form of novice monks, enter the village to beg for food, and their miraculous traces are difficult to describe.
Going more than thirty li to the east in an empty valley of Mount Budhana, I reached the forest of Shizhi, which is called the Staff Forest in Tang.
Bamboo groves and tall reeds covered the mountains and filled the valleys.
In the past, there was a Brahmin who heard that Shakyamuni Buddha was 16 feet tall, but he always had doubts and did not believe it. He then took a 16-foot bamboo staff to measure the Buddha's body.
The staff always extended beyond 16 feet, increasing in height like this, unable to reach the true height. He finally threw down the staff and left, and it took root there.
In the middle of the bamboo grove, there is a large stupa built by King Asoka.
In the past, the Tathagata stayed here for seven days, displaying great spiritual powers for the devas and humans, and expounding the profound and wonderful Dharma.

Not far from the Bamboo Grove, there was an upasaka named Jaya Sinha, who was of kshatriya caste in western India. He had a simple and unpretentious character, enjoyed the mountains and forests, lived in the illusory realm, and roamed in the ultimate reality. He thoroughly studied the profound meanings of the Buddhist and non-Buddhist scriptures, had a clear and lofty style of debate, and was leisurely and elegant in demeanor.
Åšramaá¹‡as, brÄhmaá¹‡as, non-Buddhist practitioners, kings, ministers, elders, and nobles all rushed to pay homage and seek his guidance.
Out of ten disciples, six studied under him.

As he gradually reached the age of seventy, he was engrossed in reading without weariness. He abandoned other arts and only practiced the Buddhist scriptures, spurring his body and mind, not resting day or night.
According to the Indian method, fragrant powder is made into a paste to create small stupas, five or six inches high, with the written scriptures placed inside. This is called the Dharma relics;
As the number gradually increased, a large stupa was built to house them all, and offerings were always made.

Therefore, King ViÅ›Äkha's work was to expound the wonderful Dharma with his mouth, guiding and inspiring students, and with his hands he created stupas to cultivate supreme blessings. At night he would also walk, pay homage, chant, sit in meditation, and contemplate, with no time for sleep or meals, never slackening day or night.

It still exists today, with clear water undiminished. People from far and near all come to bathe here, and old and chronic illnesses are all cured.
Beside it is a stÅ«pa where the TathÄgata walked.

Going southeast from Staff Grove for six or seven li, reaching a great mountain, in front of a horizontal ridge there is a stone stupa. In the past the TathÄgata spent two or three months here teaching the Dharma to humans and gods. At that time King BimbisÄra wanted to come and listen to the Dharma, so he cleared the mountain and piled up rocks to build steps, more than twenty steps wide and three or four li long.

Three or four li north of the great mountain there is a solitary mountain. In the past the sage Vipashyin lived here, carving out a cave in the cliff. The remaining traces still exist, and the teachings of his disciples are still being spread.

Four or five li northeast of the solitary mountain there is a small solitary mountain. On the mountain wall there is a stone chamber that can accommodate more than a thousand people. In the past the TathÄgata spent three months here teaching the Dharma.
Above the stone chamber there is a large flat rock. Indra and Brahma smeared the Buddha's body with oxhead sandalwood. The remaining fragrance on the rock is still fragrant to this day.
In the southwest corner of the Stone Chamber, there is a rocky peak, which the Indians call the Asura Palace.
In the past, there was a good man who was well-versed in spells. He invited fourteen companions and made an agreement with like-minded people to enter this rocky peak.
After walking thirty to forty li, they suddenly became greatly enlightened. They saw cities, terraces, and pavilions, all made of gold, silver, and lapis lazuli.
When these people arrived, there were young maidens standing by the door, welcoming them with joy and treating them with great courtesy.
Then, they gradually advanced to the inner city gate. Two maidservants each held a golden tray filled with flowers and incense, and came to welcome them.
They said to the people:
You should bathe in the pond, apply fragrant flowers, and then enter. This would be excellent.
Only that spell master should advance quickly.
The other thirteen people then bathed, and after entering the pond, as if forgetting something, they sat in a rice field, already thirty to forty li north of this flat plain.
Beside the stone chamber, there is a wooden bridge more than ten steps wide and four or five li long.

In the past, when King BimbisÄra was about to go to the Buddha, he cut through the valley, cleared the cliff and filled the river, either stacking stones or digging through the rocks, creating steps to reach the Buddha.
Going east from here for more than sixty li in the big mountain, I reached the city of Kushagrapura (meaning Upper Reed City in Tang).
The Upper Reed City is in the center of Magadha, the capital of the ancient kings, and many excellent auspicious fragrant reeds are produced, hence it is called the Upper Reed City.

Surrounded by lofty mountains on all four sides, it forms an outer enclosure. The west side has a narrow passage, and the north side has a mountain gate. It is longer from east to west and narrower from south to north, with a circumference of over 150 li.
The remaining ruins of the inner city have a circumference of over 30 li.
Karnikara trees are found all along the paths, with flowers containing a unique fragrance and colors as brilliant as gold. In the month of late spring, the forests are all golden in color.

On the northern peak of the mountain, there is a stupa where the Tathagata, looking towards the city of Magadha, spoke the Dharma for seven days.
West of the northern city gate of the mountain, there is Mount Vipula. I heard the local people say:
On the south side of the mountain, there were once five hundred hot springs, but now there are only a few dozen left. However, some are cold and some are warm, not all hot.
The source of the springs originates from the Anavatapta Lake south of the Himalayas. It flows underground to here, and the water is very clear and delicious, tasting the same as the original lake.
It passes through five hundred small hot hells, and the heat from the fire causes the water to become warm.
The mouths of the springs are all carved with stone, some shaped like lion or white elephant heads, some like stone tubes with flowing water, and below they are built with stone to form pools.
People from different regions all come here to bathe, and many of their chronic illnesses are cured.
The stupas and monasteries to the left and right of the hot springs are arranged in a row, all of which are the sites where the four buddhas of the past sat and walked in the past.
Since this place has mountains and water, and is inhabited by benevolent and wise people, there are also many hermits.
To the west of the hot springs is the Bihua Stone Chamber, where the World-Honored One always resided in the past.
The cave on the back wall is the palace of the asuras.
Monks who practice meditation often live in this chamber.
Sometimes strange and unusual dragons, snakes, and lions appear, and those who see them become mentally disturbed.
However, this is a sacred place where spiritual sages dwell, and those who follow their footsteps and admire their teachings forget about the disasters.
Recently, there was a monk whose precepts and conduct were pure and sincere, and who enjoyed the tranquility of seclusion. He wanted to hide in this chamber to practice meditation.
Some advised him, saying:
Do not go there!
There are many disasters and calamities there, and the harm is not small. It is difficult to attain concentration there, and you may even lose your life.
Please consider the previous matter and do not bring about regret later.
The monk said:
It is not so.
I am now aspiring to seek the Buddha's enlightenment and subdue the heavenly demons. How can this harm be worth mentioning?
He then shook his staff and went to the room.
Thereupon he set up an altar and recited incantations.
After ten days, a girl emerged from the hole and said to the monk:
The Venerable one wears dyed robes and upholds the precepts, serving as a refuge for sentient beings;
Cultivating wisdom and practicing concentration, you become a good guide for living beings.
Yet now, dwelling here, you frighten us.
Is this the teaching of the Tathagata?
The monk said:
I uphold the pure precepts and follow the sacred teachings.
Hiding in the mountains and valleys, I stay far away from worldly affairs.
Suddenly encountering this criticism, where is the fault?
She replied:
Venerable one, the sound of your chanting the mantra caused fire to enter from the outside and burn my house, causing suffering to my dependents.
I only wish that you would have compassion and not chant the mantra again.
The bhiká¹£u said:

In the past, practitioners lived here practicing meditation, aiming for the fruits of sagehood to deliver the netherworld. Seeing the strange, they were frightened and lost their lives. What can you say about your guilt?
He replied:
My karmic hindrances are already heavy, and my wisdom is shallow.
From now on, I will stay in seclusion and guard my portion. I also wish that the Venerable One would not chant the divine mantra.
The bhiká¹£u then practiced meditation as before, peacefully and without harm.

To the left of the north gate of the mountain city, on the south cliff, going east for two or three li, there is a large stone chamber where Devadatta once entered meditation.

Not far east of the stone chamber, on a flat rock there are mottled patterns resembling bloodstains. Beside it is a stupa, the place where a monk who was practicing meditation killed himself and attained the fruit of sainthood.
In the past, there was a monk who diligently concentrated his mind and body, living in seclusion to cultivate meditation for many years, but did not attain the holy fruit.
He withdrew and blamed himself, secretly sighing:

So he used this stone to stab his neck. At that time, he immediately attained the fruit of arhatship, rose into the sky, manifested supernatural powers, transformed fire to burn his body, and entered nirvana.
Admiring his noble conduct, they built this to record his merits.

In the past, during the Buddha's time, there was a bhikkhu who was sitting in meditation in the mountains, cultivating the samadhi of fruition. Although he had been diligently practicing for a long time, he had not yet attained fruition. Day and night, he continued to contemplate, not forgetting the tranquil samadhi.

The Tathagata knew that his faculties were about to be activated, so he went there to help him. From the Bamboo Grove, he went to the foot of the cliff, snapped his fingers to summon him, and stood there waiting.

The bhikkhu saw the holy assembly from afar, and his body and mind were filled with joy. He threw himself off the cliff, and because of his pure mind and respectful faith in the Buddha's words, before he even reached the ground, he had already attained fruition.
The World-Honored One said:
It is time for you to know this.
He then ascended into the sky and manifested supernatural transformations.
This was done to show his pure faith, and thus this place was sealed and recorded.

To the east of Kalandaka Bamboo Grove, there is a stupa built by King Ajatashatru (meaning Born of Hatred), also known as Ajatashatru.
After the Tathagata's nirvana, the kings shared his relics. King Ajatashatru took his share back to his country and respectfully built this stupa to make offerings.
When King Asoka developed faith, he opened the stupa to take out the relics and built another stupa. There are still some remaining relics that emit a brilliant light.
In the stupa built by King Ajatashatru, there are the relics of half of Venerable Ananda's body.
In the past, when Venerable Ananda was about to enter nirvana, he left Magadha and went to Vaishali.
The two countries were about to go to war.
Venerable Ananda felt pity for them and divided his body. The king of Magadha respectfully brought his share back to make offerings, and built this excellent site to make offerings.
Beside it is the place where the Tathagata used to walk.

Going southeast from Gu Shan Guanyin Bodhisattva's image for more than 40 li, he reached a monastery with over 50 monks, all studying the teachings of the Lesser Vehicle.
In front of the monastery, there was a large stupa with many spiritual manifestations. The Buddha once preached the Dharma for Brahma Heaven King and others for seven days here.
Beside it were the remains of the three past Buddhas' sitting and walking.
Going northeast from the monastery for more than 70 li, south of the Ganges, he reached a large village with a prosperous population. There were several celestial temples, all exquisitely carved.
Not far to the southeast, there was a large stupa where the Buddha once preached the Dharma for one night.
From here, entering the mountains and forests to the east for more than 100 li, he reached the village of Rakkhita.
In front of the monastery, there was a large stupa built by King Asoka. The Buddha once preached the Dharma for three months here.
Two or three li to the north of this place, there is a large pond, more than thirty li in circumference, with four-colored lotus flowers blooming in the four seasons.
From here, going east into a large mountain forest for more than two hundred li, I reached the country of Ilanaputrabhadra (in the territory of Central India).
